*Dian Jiang Chun*
Youling inquired: "Why does the gourd I carry never open its mouth?"
Composed in response to the imperial presence.

A tiny gourd,
born small, its stature low.
Its seeds lie within—
how can one blame it for having no mouth?
It holds heaven and earth—
who understands this principle?
Hung at the waist,
I cherish it all the more.
It surpasses the golden fish pouch.

*Recalling Peach Blossom Spring: Two Poems*
Cai Shiyuan doubted me, Shenweng, and Shichen.

Shiyuan posed a question: "What is the extension of cultivation and refinement?"
I dashed off a brief lyric in reply.

The words of long life are passed mouth to mouth,
seeking the golden elixir in its fullness.
Blending into one, becoming an immortal—
I explain it earnestly to the worthy.

Do not swallow qi,
do not recklessly transmit it—
how could one fathom the mystery of creation?
Use lead to cast into mercury, mercury into lead,
clearly inverted, again and again.

Within the piled white clouds, pluck the lotus,
each branch fragrant and richly lush.
By the shore of the numinous tortoise, auspicious winds arise,
a tower of twelve stories high.
The golden hall,
veiled in azure clouds,
cinnabar glows crimson through the crown.
Where the divine mechanism turns, ghosts and spirits commune—
the pure and true ascend to the highest palace.

*Lin Jiang Xian*
Deng Dafu released six cranes at Hunlun Hermitage and requested a poem.
Thus composed.

Do not wonder that the spirit is so plain and pale—
it fully comprehends the thousand-year pine’s crown.

The feathered immortals share a deep and kindred sorrow,
Earnestly vying to inscribe and compose,
Turning and tossing in responsive verse.
Moreover, there is the tale of the brothers of Xianyang,
Which makes one forget all cares upon hearing it.
My life has ever been marked by the signs of transcendence—
Once the brush was set to paper,
The flow could not be halted.

*Qin Yuan Chun* (Three Poems)
*Subduing Demons and Establishing Order*

As the kalpic cycle renews,
Heavenly scriptures descend with grace,
The sagely master commands the demons.
Now yin and yang are disordered,
Ghosts and spirits confounded,
Relying on cities,
Stretching across mountains and rivers.
Murderous qi chokes the sky,
Yin’s countenance usurps the day,
The myriad people suffer calamity, day after day.
Above Qingcheng,
A lapis lazuli throne appears,
Suddenly rising, towering and majestic.
The demonic hordes, enraged, brandish their weapons,
Vying to rush and attack the mountain like shuttles in a loom.
At the flash of divine radiance,
Dragons are subdued, tigers trapped;
At the thunderous roar of awe-inspiring sound,
Lightning strikes, thunder rebukes.
Order is established to transform the people,
Evil is gathered and returned to rectitude,
Life flourishes in harmony, enjoying great peace.
The winds and clouds grow still,
Revealing the heavens merging with the azure vastness,
The moon bathing in limpid waves.

*Again*

The True Unity endures forever,
One with the Great Void,
The wondrous gate opens of itself.
Since the primordial chaos first divided,
The Two Modes arrayed their scenes,
Returning again to the root,
To the golden register and the numinous terrace.
Vast qi surges forth,
The Valley Spirit nurtures transformation,
Gradually, the divine radiance is felt coming from the void.
In the most secluded depths,
One hears the dragon’s chant, the tiger’s roar,
Suddenly—wind and thunder.

How wondrous, the subtle Dao is hard to fathom,
Yet by refining the foolish, great talents are made.
Let me plainly reveal to you its form—
The clam holds the moon in the deep,
The autumn hare carries its embryo.
Men and women of lofty resolve,
High-minded scholars of old—
Do not let body and mind be sullied by worldly dust.
When merit is complete,
Freely dwell in the Purple Court,
Your name inscribed on the immortal ranks.

*Again*

Hasten to cultivate the Way,
For on close reckoning, how much time does a human life hold?
Though you may possess a thousand charms,
A myriad graces—what avail?
One morning, death comes,
And all must be cast aside.
Suddenly reflecting,
The great matter of life and death
Strikes my heart like a blade unsheathed.
Hard to detain—
The golden crow’s arrows fly swift,
The jade hare’s shuttle weaves fast.
Awaken early, let not fate deceive you,
In purity, who can match my youthful bride?
Even if in the moon’s embrace,
The Lady of the Moon were yours to command,
Or in Yue, the fairest of the land—
This fleeting romance,
I have no heart to cherish.
With a broad mind and open mouth, avoid strife.
Rely on Penglai’s might,
When the three thousand deeds are fulfilled,
Ride alone back in triumph.

*Lin Jiang Xian*
*In Reply to Yuan Gui*

All creatures endowed with life receive Heaven’s gift,
In carefree nature, their original share is one.
Let no heterodox views disturb my true essence.
Here and now, the inner master abides,
Wholly merged with transformation as human.

No more need for subtle words, so clear to the core—
Even light dust would find no cause to cling.
Only when this is attained does spirit congeal.
A hundred demons all cease their strife,
The six paths forever halt their turning.

*Man Ting Fang*

In leisure, refine your skill,
Within the wondrous workings of non-being,
Take care not to speculate or ponder.
Dragon descends, tiger submits,
True earth emerges from central yellow.
In movement, rest, sleep, and diet,
Follow the current, never stir true yang.
At the root’s return,
Spirit congeals, pulse stills,
And from the jade realm, celestial light arises.

When winds rise high, the roc’s wings soar far;
When waters run deep, the boat glides on—
Such is the principle of all things, manifest and clear.
Simply illuminate the heart, for that is the Dao,
Devote yourself wholly, and Heaven will reveal.
Idly summon spirits or call forth ghosts,
Pray for rain or sunshine—this is no madness.
Yet the deluded,
Though thunder and wind lie in their grasp,
Turn their use awry.

*Lin Jiang Xian*
*In Reply to Yuan Gui, After Reading Yang Xi’s Biography*

Since ancient times, the pure and numinous descend in wondrous ways,
Lady An came to Master Yang.
Their karmic meeting was beyond common bonds.
For a time, immortal airs took form,
Yet the true Dao has no kin.

Only Yuan Gui could seek and inquire,
Deeply sharing this intent.
All should together appreciate and compose new verses,
Lest dust-bound scholars
Mock the celestial beings.

*Man Ting Fang*
*To the Tune of the Perfected One, Harmonizing with Yuan Gui’s Rhyme*

Mind and realm both pure,
Joy shared across ancient and modern,
Noble paths—do not say they lack a guide.
The celestial gate stands lofty and wondrous,
Only the utmost person may open it.
How could this compare to ordinary sentiments?
In the square inch of the heart,
Not a speck of dust is stored.
Still, one must trust—
Gold firm, stone unyielding,
A single resolve never wavers.

True origin,
Truly lovable,
True teacher, true friend,
Rejoice in their guilelessness.
Among them, even more free and untrammeled,
Careless of form and frame.
Yet is this not solemn awakening?
Relying on true essence,
Transforming the mortal frame.
When the numinous meets,
The world’s snares of dust—
Speak not of their origins.

*Dong Xian Ge*

Atop the solitary peak’s summit,
None can reach.
Ten thousand miles of empty space, boundless and vast.
In autumn’s high, still scene,
Mists roll back, clouds withdraw,
Wind and dew enfold—
Only the moon’s radiance shines high.
Fleeting life, a passing traveler,
In fine weather, a fair night,
Drunk with dance and wild song, mistaking dusk for dawn.
Who knows the one nature,
Perfect as the Ganges,
In an instant—eternal,
Light ageless?
Yet they vie to face the moon,
Debating profit, discoursing fame,
Never thinking of the fleeting shadow,
Stealthily hastening youth away.

*Yu Jia Ao*
*Composed Over Wine for Jie Fu*

Hastily the cup is raised to share a laugh,
A life of illness and suffering thus passes.
Friendship and righteousness run deep as earth.
Hearts illumine each other—
Let no one of today
Be mocked by those of old.

Lamps flicker softly in the quiet mountains,
Orchid’s fine fragrance, pine and bamboo flourish.
Finding ease beyond the dusty world,
Incense just begins to rise—
Neighboring roosters, hold back
From hastening the clear dawn.

*Geng Lou Zi*
*Harmonizing with Yuan Gui’s "Hall of Celestial Harmony"*

By primordial essence,
Seal the mouth, turn the gaze inward—
Beyond things, the body finds no ground for death.
Zi Jie’s errors,
Ji Zhen’s faults:
Non-action twisted into action.

Only empty the heart,
Fill the belly,
And secretly merge with the vast heavens as one.
Huayang Cave,
Guanghan Palace—
All lie within the square inch of every mind.

*[Hai Qian Ying]*
*Two Poems*
*Inscribed on the Wall of Guo Nanzhong’s Hermitage*

Deep in the hidden ravine,
I ask the cowherd, the woodcutter boy—
Both lose their way.
Wilderness tangled with reeds,
Serpents and dragons rise and vanish,
Jade Gorge plunges into empty paths.
No craving for wild-goose pagodas’ glory,
Only keeping to the fish’s cold, pure abyss.
This toil—
Hold fast, and the gods themselves will shield you.

Sudden awakening,
No turning back—
A single spark of emptiness,
Ten thousand kalpas without past or present.
The root of embryonic breathing runs deep,
The spirit spring’s cave is secret,
In stillness, the Yang fire is nurtured and tuned.
Ask not of earth’s endurance or heaven’s span—
Simply gather causes to bear fruit.
Do not squander,
For I reveal to you the true foundation of the Celestial Valley.

*Again*

Passions coil, knowledge binds.

Alas for those of this age who fail to awaken—
true joy lies in the wine.
Unbridled speech invites transgression,
deluded minds lose their conduct,
yet they claim it was the maddening draught’s fault.
Know well that in drunken dance and wild song,
there too resides innate knowing and true awareness.
Unmoored,
as warmth circulates freely,
through the Three Passes and Three Meridians.

Fallen and carefree,
a wanderer of leisure—
deep in the realm of intoxication,
wind and moon ever repay the drunk.
Empty blossoms’ tidings,
radiant and revealed,
self and other—all forgotten.
No need to ask of market brews or village ferments,
simply sip lightly, pour low.
Yet they scorn and deride,
vying to speak of sobriety,
each word a mistake.

*Embroidered Needle Fixed*

Snowy night, fishing boat,
evening wind subsides.
I myself pole the skiff,
gliding with the current to watch the snow.
Mountains rise like jade peaks,
forests stand as silver trees,
high and low—no distinction remains.
The heart’s nature, clear and limpid,
with not a single old friend to speak to.
Suddenly, this floating life
seems to dwell in heaven’s halls,
a palace of crystal.

All sounds and shadows of the dust-world cease.
Piercing emptiness without bounds,
water and sky merge.
Vast qi surges and fills,
true work runs deep and thick—
through the long night, no fear of biting cold.
Ashamed of my own paltriness,
knowing only how to chase warmth and heat.
I halt the oars and laugh,
entrusting all that matters
to the wild plum and river moon.

*Spring Comes from Heaven Above*

The crane cries, bearing the imperial decree.

The earth lies smooth as jade,
as the sea stills its waves,
mountains gather their clouds and mists.
The Three Radiance stand empty and bright,
the Eight Directions clear and pure—
one moon illumines all heavens.
From the flowing rosy dawn,
a sigh as pearl-like grains
slowly descend through boundless emptiness.
Beyond form and speech,
a thousand Perfected bow to the Pole Star,
ten thousand mysteries turn toward the Origin.

That night when the crane cried at midnight,
moved by the true talisman and sacred script,
he received the transmission in person.
Azure dragon-script shimmered,
crimson turtle-seals congealed,
and scarlet-robed beings—beasts without scales or wings—appeared.
When merit was complete and fruit attained,
the true teaching was bequeathed,
and the radiant immortals soared through the expanse.
A thousand years have passed,
yet the hundred-and-first lamp continues the flame,
its light boundless and bright.

*More Drops of Water*
(To the tune of the Perfected One)

Right or wrong—
both are struck down together,
lest they kindle the demon’s fire.
Speak of the conditioned,
and harm the stubborn void;
dwell instead in the midst of seeing and gazing.
The wind of sages and worthies
blows where it will—
why vie with cleverness and wit?
With poetry and wine,
let us seize this leisure,
laughing with verdant brows.

*Moon over the Jasper Terrace*
(Celebrating the Lantern Festival and Longevity)

Heaven unfolds its auspicious fate,
recalling the revival of the Han,
the resurgence of the fiery Liu.
In this meeting of enlightened sovereign and worthy minister,
the Eight Directions know wind and rain in harmony.
How rare the hour when the Sage was born in Shen,
just as the Yellow River ran clear for a thousand years!
Auspicious clouds embrace,
rosy dawn reflects.
Flying immortals bow,
the Star of Literature shines bright.
A felicitous sign—
for the Master’s true essence nurtures fortune,
and heaven and earth rejoice together.
The fragrance of roses fills the Lantern Festival’s scene,
while the divine light of Heaven’s Eye gleams like a mirror.
Manifesting dragon-pattern and phoenix-form,
he subdues all demons and returns them to the true.
Receiving the Primordial’s mandate,
he established the teaching and opened the way;
awakening to the supreme Dao,
the heart is empty and the spirit attains.
Flourishing the lineage,
illuminating the true realm—
together with non-being,
rejoicing in purity and stillness.
Everlasting,
he delivers the three paths and six destinies,
as immortals and gods bear witness together.

*Wind through the Pines*
(To the tune of Jie Fu)

Amid the inch-wide field, deep plowing and careful weeding—
behold the true hero.
Night after night, he ascends the star terrace,
never tiring of waters green and clouds red.
Such are his pure companions and plain-spoken friends,
often gazing at one another, smiling beneath the clear sky.

Jade steps and jasper chants layered in emerald,
with daylily lush and verdant.
Skilled in drinking the rosy dawn’s nectar, why refuse intoxication?
No need to count the thousand cups of worldly dust.
At dawn and dusk, he departs to face the origin—
how could he bear to abandon the pine of the great man?

*Cherishing the Fleeting Time*
*(To the tune of Dui Zhu Fu)*

Hollow-hearted, stalwart-stemmed, vying in grace and detachment,
by the balustrade winter and summer alike.
Frost-laden winds, snow-laden hues in deepening dusk—
yet never do the slender branches and delicate stems wither.
Within the heart’s intent lie the sorrows of dust and sand;
listen closely to the strings’ songs, swift and slow.
No disdain for the verdant green that opens the blue eye—
gazing together, as if accustomed to the Taiyuan family’s ways.

*Pure Serene Music*
*(Qing Ping Yue)*

Before heaven and after, the true earth conceals divine elegance.
Its wondrous workings naturally follow the fire’s timing,
steaming through each node until fully permeated.
No distinction between dragon musk, sandalwood, or aloes—
all enter the nose and penetrate the heart.
When the smoke’s message ceases,
the whole body transforms into true gold.

*Silken Canopy*
*(Su Mu Zhe)*
*(To the rhyme of Master Wu, harmonizing with Yuan Gui)*

Before heaven’s birth, after heaven’s long span,
the Dao holds its true canon—
listen closely to what was received then.
Just as one loses the sky and mistakes the Dipper for guidance,
fearing this frail form,
by ill fortune, may wither and decay.

*West River Moon*
*(Xi Jiang Yue)*
*(Again harmonizing)*

**Reed Door Open Wide**

The thatched door swings open to vast stillness,
the cold window’s jade gleam bathed in bamboo’s pure radiance.
A wind steals in through the five-fragrance curtain,
bringing yet another gift of fine sound.

Know this: even the tiniest may enter,
a luminous pearl cradled in the womb of forgetfulness.
Wild revels and night feasts—right or wrong?
The moon-palace immortals bear no shadow.

---

*Two Southern Village Songs*
*(Harmonizing with Yuan Gui)*

**I**
No help for these lost flocks,
bound fast in taste, hue, and sound.
Let them change heads, swap faces—what grief?
They’ll not be stained; then, they’ll not be heeded.

Spring departs, autumn returns—
do not let the twelve hours pass in vain jade.
Hold fast the true, wondrous essence of nature,
and cultivate. Dust’s toil is steep;
the Dao, how level.

**II**
Long absent from the spring terrace,
waiting to mount the nine heavens.
Too weary to ask others—deep meaning lies there—
amid dust and haze,
hard to ride the perverse winds and touch the sacred embryo.

The water-railed pavilion mirrors the mountain studio,
leisurely gazing until the head turns homeward.
Long since I’ve thanked old friends for their letters’ subtle intent—
how slight! How could I summon the zither at my waist,
sweep my sleeves, and come?

---

*Gazing at the South River*
*(Watching a Game of Chess)*

**Gazing at the South River**
*(Watching a Game of Chess, continued)*

The autumn board lies still—
black and white, two caskets evenly paired.
Mountains and waters best suit shared delight;
zither and books win the Dao’s close kinship.
Each game, each turn, renewed.

Beneath the pine’s shade,
how many springs have passed?
As fate allows, I’ve played my hand,
yet vying for first drains the spirit.
Ever do I secretly yield.

---

*Twelve Poems in Praise of Xiyuan*
*(Matching Yuan Gui’s Rhymes, with Preface)*

I have long admired Xiyuan—its cliffs rise sheer, free of vulgar form, its sparse pines and dense bamboos threading all directions, its verdant jade gleaming in radiant exchange. Heaven shaped these noble heights, and earth’s genius shines thus. Often we say to one another: *We dwell in the ruins of the Perfected Ones yet remain unaware.*

Ascending Playful Pearl Peak, I see tiger-crouching dragons leaping, distant walls and far ridges all beneath my gaze. Here I examine the site, erect a hall, and raise its inscribed plaque. Flowers in the water, vegetables in the garden, mountain light and fresh bamboo, the sunlit hut ever more serene—I have found my home.

Once, longing for return, I saw twelve verses in kindred voice and so harmonized with them.

---

**Xiyuan is fine—**
a transcendent’s structure crowns the transcendent peak.
One crane’s nature, pure, clears my dwelling;
ten thousand dragons’ wind and rain stir the frosty void.
Lofty, still, vast—too indolent for worldly care.

**Heaven and earth rejoice—**
mountains and waters flow in tranquil communion.
Walking, sitting, lying, I cherish scenes beyond the dust;
emptiness and silence are the Daoist’s way.
No trifling joy compares.

**Xiyuan is fine—**
dragon’s head and tiger’s brow rise high.
Wind and rain ever gladden the clear cosmos;
ridges and forests surge like waves.
Chanting and singing, I find my poetic boldness.

**Great joy is complete—**
its fair renown meets its fitting encounter.

At the pure altar of the Dipper, jade tablets are cast and feathered missives sent;
the Primordial is invoked in joyous assembly, golden blades held aloft.
Now my person stands apart from the world’s dust, free to scratch my head in ease.

**Xiyuan is fine—**
the cliffside lodge is hewn from pine, its beams weighed down with age.
Before the Five-Dipper Grotto, I pour jade-like wine in study;
half-drunk, beyond the window, I caress my golden cup.
Unburdened, I am at leisure.

**Emerald hues—**
jade bamboo newly planted.
Let the wind come, but spare the ancient trees from sway;
let the rain fall in season to wash the verdant moss.
Such is the vexation of a poet’s talent.

**Xiyuan is fine—**
spring days lengthen with the rising sun.
I care not to ask of the third-month’s scenes among men;
I ever long for the celestial realm of ten thousand flowers.
In secluded delight, I am momentarily wild.

**Laughter and song—**
vast, resounding hymns.
A thousand deeds vie in the wind-swept valley’s splendor;
when the threefold clouds return, moonlight bathes the forest.
The musk’s fragrance lingers like orchid.

**Xiyuan is fine—**
welcoming summer, I sprinkle the scorching winds.
By the red-brocade stones, a lone flute plays;
on Old Zhang’s crag, I linger among the clustered peaks.
At times, I grasp the rod that transforms into a dragon.

**The zither’s jade tones—**
dawn’s light leans upon the wutong tree.
Though age may tarnish my literary works, they flourish within the court;
mountains and rivers, forests and wild pavilions stand empty.
Crimson flames blaze bright within.

**Xiyuan is fine—**
the Daoist cherishes autumn’s scene.
When the season arrives, the heavens naturally turn solemn;
deep in the night, I still delight in the moon’s full radiance.
A long whistle presses down upon the azure peaks.

**Indeed, with wine—**
how hard it is to part from song’s edge.
Wherever firewood is felled for charcoal,
now is the time to taste the new rice and celebrate the harvest year.
The youths dance like embryonic immortals.

**Xiyuan is fine—**
winter’s pines stand amid the snow.
Hand in hand upon the stone altar, I receive the beloved scene;
in stillness, I watch heaven and earth enter the pure palace.
Just like the Great Mao Peak.

**Sleeves and hems tinkling—**
the zither’s case holds deep sentiment.
Before the Moon-Blowing Grotto, I hold jade within my lips;
the enchanting charm stirs, shifting to the Yellow Bell’s tone.
Emotions arise from within.

**Xiyuan is fine—**
the secluded path does not slope awry.
The mountain valley’s seclusion remains unchanged in hue;
the pond’s emptiness and stillness bear not a single flaw.
One fishes at the water’s edge.

**A small immortal barge—**
one longs to gaze upon your abode.
The returning oars turn with the sun, as if beholding a mirror;
the drifting boat descends with the stars, like riding a spindle.
Wind and rain scatter the cold sands.

**Xiyuan is fine—**
the divine grotto seeks its own accord.
By the water, fields are tilled as the mountain stream rushes;
hewing the mountain, a path is opened where tiny blossoms float.
Footprints of the old man remain.

**Forgetting the ten thousand things—**
the crisp qi gathers the white clouds.

The Director of Destinies once sought quiet repose,
Ziyang’s steps were truly light along the secluded path.
Longing to follow this master’s wanderings.

**Xiyuan is fine—**
one dwells within a palace of crystal.
Ever wishing the Jade Spring might cleanse the tripod,
just as Dragon Well reaches Celestial Peak.
Truly, a splendid legacy remains.

Pure to the depths,
how could it rival the flourishing of Li and Tang?
Naturally steeped, the rock’s clarity presses before the crag;
not confined, the mountain’s clouds drift beyond the heavens.
Limpid and luminous, it fills the heart.

**Xiyuan is fine—**
rain clears, the red gauze gathers.
Emerald waters still beckon the old angler;
green cliffs chill, rousing the fisherman’s home.
Spring tea is brewed beneath the canopy.

Wind vast and boundless,
brocade shadows grace the stone screen.
Above the cauldron, jade bamboo is struck;
westward, perch are drawn through crimson sands.
Ask not of joy’s distant shore.

**Xiyuan is fine—**
once more toward the western courtyard.
Watching evening chrysanthemums bloom beyond the square acre,
beside cold plum blossoms, six-petaled snowflakes take flight.
Three cranes arrive as one.

The world now clear,
emptiness alone is prized—non-action supreme.
Wearing the moon, the night still holds parting;
on the fragrant plain of Yu, no need to wander lost.
Here, one shakes out one’s robes and returns.

---

**Geng Lou Zi**
Again in rhyme to the Perfected One

Reciting the true scriptures,
hoping for ten thousand repetitions—
yet the fire of ignorance remains unquenched.
One should turn back,
explore true emptiness,
and melt into serene solitude.

Since ancient times, where do people abide?
Vainly clinging to fame and profit.
Cast off worldly burdens,
cultivate quiet leisure—
the elixir of jade preserves youth.

---

**Su Mu Zhe**
Embracing the lone zither,
plucking a short melody.
Seated alone in the secluded pavilion,
all day without a visitor.
Only delighting in rosy clouds, a long and proud whistle,
the bright moon and clear wind—
eternal friends of past and present.

Comprehending heaven and earth,
knowing yin and yang,
too weary to join the dusty toil,
the ceaseless race.
Loving to gaze high, the white day fades—
let others chase
the jade hare and golden crow.

---

**Jian Zi Mu Lan Hua**
Presented to Jianyi, Wang Jiefu

In the bitter cold of winter,
the sun’s return brought near-falling snow.
Pines vie with the clouds,
their towering forms in the pavilion sighing at late-withering.

The ancients hesitated,
entering the mountain forests’ depths.
Past and present align—
best to follow the reed pipes and songs, finding joy alone.

---

**Man Ting Fang**
Once more ascending...

**Regulating the Three Passes**

Regulating the Three Passes, harmonizing the four limbs,
in stillness, no care for the vexations of mutual strife.
In profound union with the Great Tenuity,
the Primordial Beginning speaks to the immortals.
The Jade Scriptures are re-edited, wondrous canons,
inscribed on the Western Terrace and Southern Peak, chapter by chapter.
Yet what is most revered—
the body’s field in this world,
the heart turned toward the Great Clarity of Heaven.

**Beyond the Clouds**
Once descended as a sage,
bowing at the golden altar by night,
a lofty chariot lingering in delay.
Discoursing on jade blossoms and divine nectar,
form and spirit made whole.
The body must rely on wondrous qi,
the spirit abides in the Yellow Court’s cinnabar field.
The true essence’s purport—
luminous radiance as aid,
heaven and earth preserving long life.

**Watching the River South**
*To Mingquan*

Autumn night’s affairs,
in the moon’s embrace, bamboo stands tall.
Clear echoes—with whom do they clamor over earth and water?
A gentle breeze sends me down the eaves’ pillars.
Waxing and waning—how could they bear emotion?

The Way of Zhongnan,
layered with laughter and song.
The cinnabar gate freezes at night, horses depart;
the Yellow River at dawn reflects a boat adrift.
Riding side by side, they come and go as one.

**Song of the River Spirit**

Colored clouds, pavilions, and auspicious mist settle.
Rain just cleared, the moon veils all in brightness.
Night still, celestial winds
blow down the strains of *Steps in the Void*.
Where do they ascend to court so late?
A pair of phoenixes, small,
and five clouds, light.

Falling flowers, flowing waters—two gates of feeling.
Resentment has no hold,
dreams refuse to form.
Leaning on every railing,
the Chu wind remains clear.
Dew drips from pine tips, the world hushed—
unfurling the precious seal,
reciting the *Yellow Court*.

**Magpie Bridge Immortal**
*To Mingquan*

Spirit clear, heart wondrous,
mountains long, waters distant—
what fate determines the year we meet again?
A single patch of cloud flies through the clear sky,
stirring in me boundless imagining.

One gate to transformation,
ninefold blossoms of grace and dew—
only wishing for a clear direction.
Bamboo winds often rise in the purple haze of the Northern Culmen,
as if with intent,
permitting a return home.

**Water Tune Prelude**
*The Master’s liberation in Sizhou, later manifesting in Qingcheng, bequeathing the truth to the Perfected Sa Shoujian.*

High Perfected leave wondrous instructions,
enlightened beings rescue the deluded masses.
Heart pure, conduct immaculate—
celestials, humans, the common and sacred, all turn in devotion.
Not in refining essence or moving qi,
not in soaring petitions or treading the Dipper,
but in a heart disordered by doubt.
Only rid falsehood and delusion,
the heart’s ground uniting with the divine.

Awakening to true emptiness,
breaking free from the world’s snares,
severing the mechanisms of the passes.
Nurturing my vast qi,
commanding thunder, dispatching lightning, shaking celestial might.
Merging the hundred spirits into one,
a single thought piercing heaven and earth—
only then is non-action fully realized.
With a shout, wind and rain arise,
aiding the world in an enlightened age.

**Six Songs of Ascending the Clear Dawn**

*First Watch, First Point*
The first watch begins,
city gates half-closed, wayfarers refine the elixir.
A thatched hut, carefree and unburdened,
a lone lamp’s light, pure and void.
The rush mat steadies the unrestrained body,
cross-legged in great stillness, the heart unmoving.
The moon’s wheel emerges from the sky’s edge,
a nameless pearl revealed in the emptiness.

*Second Watch, Second Point*
The second watch deepens,
palace bells fall silent, night sinks.
The bright moon fills the sky like molten gold,
sharing its light and shadow, no dusk or gloom.
Rising to idly pluck the stringless zither,
its ancient tones startle the heart.
The zither silenced, singing alone, chanting alone—
pine winds and mountain streams, all know the tune.

*Third Watch, Third Point*
The third watch at its height,
mist disperses, clouds withdraw, wind stills.
Moonlight bursts into the crystal palace,
all directions, above and below, one vast emptiness.
Radiance pervades, as in the land of Hua Xu,
through endless ages, no beginning, no end.
An iron serpent dances like a flowing rainbow,
riding backward on a white phoenix, roaming Kongtong.

*Fourth Watch, Fourth Point*
The fourth watch lengthens,
the Ox submits to the Rat, the heart untroubled.
The cinnabar furnace’s fire births new fragrance,
the host of yin stripped away, true yang restored.
The Metal Maiden and Wood Lad rejoice in harmony,
toasting in succession, cups never ceasing.
Host and guest reversed, yet no sorrow—
as the night wanes, parting still brings forgetfulness.

*Fifth Watch, Fifth Point*
The fifth watch wanes,
the azure void’s wind and dew press cold upon mortals.
Fusang pushes forth a red silver platter,
city gates stir once more with the clamor of the world.
The two luminaries of light and dark clash,
life and death interchanging in ceaseless flux.
Within the Daoist’s chamber, the heavens are vast—
the sun climbs three poles before the gate opens.

Alone I walk, alone I sit,
alone I sing, alone I harmonize.
Daily I pass through the streets,
I know not myself—who knows me?
The world’s dawn and dusk follow the four seasons,
but the mystery’s message does not shift.
Gaze upon the face—do you recognize it?
When you know, join the chorus: *luo luo li*.

**Spring in Qin Garden**
*Using Master Wu’s rhymes, presented to Yuan Gui*

Moreover, there is a level path,
straight through the mysterious pass,
as all attest.
May the ten thousand demons scatter,
all dusts dissolve in this moment;
the zither’s heart harmonious and refined,
heavenly nature pure and perfect.
Not trusting the common stream,
can the lofty step be turned back?
Clinging to form and sound, emotions stretch further.
The true message—
how to awaken it?
I speak briefly to the wise.

Though fate may turn green again,
the worldly scholar cannot but sigh.
Silence and focus for the wondrous,
leisure abundant, joy scarce;
once attained, carefree,
eternally free from worry’s searing.
Reflections gleam in the limpid pool,
echoes flow through the empty valley—
the karma-fire extinguished, all is the auspicious lotus.
Secure and peaceful,
firm as earth,
enduring as heaven.

**Eulogy**
*Eulogy for the Liberation in Sizhou, Winter of the Bingwu Year of Jingkang*

A bronze mirror, one face,
layers of green jade mountains.
Suddenly, the boat departs by night,
traces shifting to inquire of the grotto-heaven.
The precious hall’s incense clouds gather,
no one—yet the ten thousand images at ease.
Beneath the western mountains, the red sun,
mist and rain fall in silent streams.

*The Sixth Scroll of the Recorded Sayings of the Perfected Lord Xu Jing, the Thirty-Third Celestial Master, concludes here.*

*The Seventh Scroll of the Recorded Sayings of the Perfected Lord Xu Jing, the Thirty-Third Celestial Master, begins.*

**Five-Character Quatrains**

*Parrot*
Virtue’s numinous abode in five,
phoenix-crowned, fresh with radiance.
Mouth agape—
awakening those lost in dreams.

*Inscribed at the Elixir-Refining Cliff*
Cranes alight where pines host guests,
lichen fades, leaving stone unclothed.
This floating world—
white-haired old friends grow few.

*Playful Chant*
In the prime of my downfall,
all laugh at my madness.
Yet when I move—
the vast sea stretches boundless.

*Bamboo*
Rain passes o’er the riverbank’s prelude,
wind arrives, the courtyard railings clear.
Good friends abide—
into night, listening to autumn’s voice.

*Fan of the Forest Librarian*
Nine luan birds attend jade beasts,
eight phoenixes offer golden lingzhi.
The song is exquisite—
the Dark Maiden sings pure verses.

*Elder of Dongyang Grotto, Mount Qingcheng*
Seeking the ancient grotto of Qingcheng,
my name inscribed on the cinnabar terrace.
Daily reciting the *Yellow Court*,
auspicious clouds descend in response.

*Impromptu at the Rustic Pavilion*
Sun and moon—twin fireflies,
heaven and earth—a magpie’s nest.
The rustic pavilion has frost-sealed doors—
who dares knock idly?

---

**Six-Character Quatrains**

*Inscribed at the Pavilion of Contentment, Chongxian Abbey*
This nature originally void of all things,
even a drop of water is round and luminous.
Ask where the master finds contentment—
before the pavilion, moonlit and wind-clear.

*Impromptu in the Chamber of Stillness*
Poverty has pure wind and bright moon,
wealth lacks rouge and powder.
At midnight and noon, the phoenix faces the Primal Origin,
departing and returning with thunder and lightning in tow.

---

**Seven-Character Quatrains**

*Bell*

**Seven-Character Quatrains**

*Bell*
Forged of golden essence, the Dipper’s stars hang high,
how many years has it graced the jade tower’s height?
Most fitting in the fifth watch’s fading dream—
one strike pierces through the white-clouded sky.

*On a Window*
Unintentional, it earnestly veils the bright moon;
intentional, it deliberately screens the red dust.
From this, the empty chamber ever births whiteness,
seizing spring within the Peach Blossom Grotto’s bounds.

*White Chrysanthemum*
Before it bloomed beneath Tao’s hedge,
the west wind lent its force to blow.
Moonlight probed by night its snowy sheen—
clearly, two or three branches of lingering frost.

*Inscribed at the Cauldron-Washing Spring*
Within the Abbey of Ascendant Truth, the Dharma unfolds;
a single pool, its limpid spring unceasing.
Of old, the Celestial Master of Han washed his cauldron here,
hence its name.
Now, beside the pool, a small pavilion stands,
its name inscribed to proclaim it.
May its secluded radiance never fade,
its numinous scene forever pure—thus I extol it in verse.
For millennia, waves of azure, ever clear,
the scene makes me forget not my ancestor’s grace.
Joyfully, I know it once borrowed strength;
the pavilion complete, its name proves not in vain.

*Hao Ranzi Observes a Bamboo Staff*
Once a branch from Ziyou’s garden,
today it parts to rest within my hand.
Pity its lofty integrity, void of all things—
in wild mountains, walking, I find it my companion.

*Two Poems Presented to the Cave Elder of Mount Qingcheng*
The immortals embrace the One, nurturing the subtle and profound;
after nine years’ work, they ascend in broad daylight.
The Dao resides in the present—one must transmit it in due course;
why conceal heaven’s mystery today?

Long have I rejoiced in our meeting,
how could I begrudge the shared arts of the Dao?
When one day your work is complete and you lightly ascend,
you shall serve as a ladder for me in the heavens.

*For the Departure of the Venerable Miaoying to Qiantang*
The Supreme Truth’s palace halls are newly built above;
returning, you first receive the purple imperial decree.
At the appointed place where Heaven’s Eye and Cave’s Radiance meet,
your star-crowned self should not brave wind and dust.

*Nine Poems on Hut Dwelling*
Tiles intact, walls of earth firm,
fences encircle, their gaps sealed by toil.
Visitors may mock the lack of adornment—
wind and rain must be met with steadfast rest.

Before the hut, peach and plum vie in spring’s bloom;
amid snow, only the plum’s flowers appear.
Do not say the branches differ—
their roots diverge, not planted by human hands.

Spring silkworms spin their threads to become moths;
autumn swallows, fledged, forsake their mud nests.
The mountain pheasant, long hidden in its den,
may yet transform into a dragon, entering misty waves.

The towering pine does not lean on the grove,
its branches high, coiling to shade a thousand acres.
Last night, wine-sodden, I woke to wind and rain’s fury—
in midair, faintly, I heard the dragon’s song.

Southern mountains after rain, northern peaks emerge;
last night’s moonlit sky, today’s clear dawn.
Clouds unfurl and coil of their own accord—
the Great Void, through endless ages, remains ever bright.

Do not envy the hut’s pure scenery;
know that joy is born from hardship.
Before the mountain, seekers pass all day,
many speak of untrodden paths as impassable.

Though the brushwood gate stands, it is never barred;
guests come and go as they please.
For days, the mountain’s cold has stilled all sound—
on the rush mat, seated upright, I find deeper peace.

On fine days, warm winds invite me forth;
when mist and rain gather, I return to rest.
Clouds, woodcutters, and herders by the stream—
none are as free as this eccentric man.

Bell and drum resound at dawn and dusk;
tea smoke and cooking smoke rise in turn.
The cloud-robed, rosy-girdled mountain dweller,
year after year, sits motionless, without a single care.

*Sent to Yuan Gui*
The sun not yet at noon, the air is bright;
the jade flask’s spirit stirs, bound for the western source.
I envy the grassy terrace, where we do not go together—
may the bamboo’s wind bring you secluded coolness.

*Lotus Flower*
Faint red blooms, delicate fragrance,
a leisurely one plucks it, sends it to a mountain chamber.
Only its green purity transcends dust and grime—
it must outshine all other flowers in grace.

*Exhortation to Disciples Returning to the Mountains*
Past kalpas’ causes meet in this kalpa’s gathering;
yesterday’s visage, today’s transformation.
In the world, seas turn to mulberry fields—
beware lest you return to display your puppet’s guise.

*Instructions to Disciple Tang*
You seek to aid the people, not for yourself;
I crave the Dao’s cultivation, heedless of poverty.
You must strive with resolve to achieve your work—
lest, through procrastination, you grow old in vain.

*Composed After Transmitting Blessings*
The Daoist’s vow is as boundless as heaven,
only when all beings are delivered will I deliver myself.
If even the slightest speck remains unblessed,
I shall never forsake the path to heaven’s ascent.

*Seeing Off Xu Zhengzhi of Nine Dragons to Mount Magu*
Treading through sunny snow, crossing the rapids,
who can follow the crane’s traces or cloud’s trail?
Like your coming, you depart with nothing—
yet, gathering your return, you are the Three Mountains.

*Matching Rhymes on the Moon, Assigned the Character "Clear"*
The azure vault, limpid and clear,
a single moon, tender-hearted, bright across the four seas.
Within the flowered courtyard’s empty halls,
the feathered one’s heart and gall grow cold.

*Visiting a Friend, Not Met—Inscribed*
Within the hut, one walks the path outside;
outside the hut, one comes to sit within.
Haphazardly patched with thatch, loosely bound—
year after year, wind and rain rend it anew.

Here ends *The Recorded Sayings of the Thirty-Third Celestial Master, Xu Jingzhen, the Vacant Serenity Perfected Lord*, Scroll Seven.

chunks.original_text: 三十代天师虚靖真君语录 经名：三十代天师虚靖真君语录北宋张继先撰，明张宇初编卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》正一部。 目录 序 卷一 文 卷二 五言古诗 卷三 歌行 卷四 五言律诗 联句 卷五 七言律诗 卷六 词颂 卷七 五言绝句 六言绝句 七言绝句 三十代天师虚靖真君语录序 宇宙之间，锺光岳灵淑之气者，惟人。 而人之修乎身也。 有诸内必形诸外，固凡蕴蓄之素者，其能已於言乎。 虽老庄氏之学，堕肢体，黜聪明，凡役乎外者，一切斥绝，务一返乎内。 而至於垂世立教之道，亦必因言而后达且着焉。 由是观之，游方之外者，岂尽以言为无所用者哉。 盖其於言也，若太空行云，澄渊微澜，随其动止而成文，不可以迹见之也。 若儒之於言也，达则雄迈，放逸之情肆； 穷则羁愁，感慨之语发者，异矣。 虽然，其道隆神化之久，与天为徒久，岂必以言之有无，而后谓之至哉。 三十代祖虚靖真君，以灵悟宿植，遭熙洽之朝。 在崇宁、靖康问，徽庙崇道尤笃，而真仙辈出。 与真君上下一时者，若徐神翕、王文卿、林灵素也。 凡驱禁祟，平潮孽，验萦桧，往往有异征。 暨国运艰否，预达灾朕，及致风霆旸雨，特指顾问。 其道神行着，诚足以羽仪天朝，泽被含品矣。 虽相去数百载，迨今人犹道慕之。 岂惟夸一时而后竟泯泯无闻者比哉。 旧传《应化录》，载述勋行详矣。 凡真君流示世教之语，陶冷性灵之篇，又皆足以警迷启蔽，非游神於胚辉泱儿之初，蝉蜕於胶辐尘滓之表，无毫忽足以介其中者，其所造诣，能若是哉。 四方传诵J愿见者惜不获其全。 往尝刊行，久亦遗缺，因采之名山，重镘诸梓，以广其传。 庶俾冠褐之士，慕向之流，探索於言外意表，以悟火符之秘，穷铅汞之妙，有余师矣。 以是而进乎道德之域，若所谓广漠之野，虚无之滨，当层峰高林之问，风清月霁之夕，哦咏其空歌灵韵，林唱泉答，又焉知其霓旌霞佩之不来降也哉。 其可不与老庄氏之言而并传乎。 宇初忝嗣匪才，岂足以尽其赞颂扬美，尝惧有所逸坠，姑序其盘於首，以俟诸大手笔焉。 岁洪武二十八年乙亥中元后上吉日正一嗣教道合无为阐祖光范真人领道教事嗣汉四十三代天师嗣孙宇初斋沐再拜馑序 三十代天师虚靖真君语录卷之一 嗣孙四十三代天师宇初编次 文 心说
chunks.translated_text:
**Preface to the Recorded Sayings of the Thirtieth-Generation Celestial Master, Perfected Lord of Empty Tranquility**

Within the cosmos, the qi of radiant mountains and numinous peaks is concentrated in humanity alone. Yet when humans cultivate the self, what is inwardly contained must manifest outwardly. How could one whose essence is so profoundly stored refrain from giving it voice? Though the teachings of Laozi and Zhuangzi advocate the abandonment of the body, the rejection of sensory brilliance, and the absolute renunciation of all that ensnares one externally—striving instead to return wholly within—even the Dao of transmitting teachings to the world and establishing guidance must rely upon words to be conveyed and made manifest.

From this, we may observe: those who wander beyond the mundane—do they truly regard words as entirely without use? For them, words are like clouds drifting through the vast sky or the faintest ripples upon a limpid abyss, forming patterns with their movement and stillness, yet leaving no trace to be discerned. This differs from the words of the Confucians: when flourishing, their speech is bold and unrestrained, their emotions unbridled; when in adversity, their words are bound by sorrow, their sentiments filled with lament. Nevertheless, the Dao endures through the ages, its spiritual transformations as eternal as Heaven itself. Must one await the presence or absence of words to deem it supreme?

The Thirtieth-Generation Ancestor, Perfected Lord of Empty Tranquility, possessed innate wisdom and karmic roots, flourishing during the reign of Emperor Huizong, when the court revered the Dao with particular devotion. Between the Chongning and Jingkang eras, the imperial house’s veneration of the Dao was profound, and true immortals emerged in abundance. Among those who ascended and descended in the same era as the Perfected Lord were Xu Shenxi, Wang Wenqing, and Lin Lingsu. In exorcising malevolent spirits, calming tidal disasters, and verifying divine omens—whether bending cypress branches or summoning auspicious signs—they frequently demonstrated extraordinary efficacy. When the nation’s fortunes waned and hardship arose, the Perfected Lord foresaw calamities and portents, and at the sovereign’s command, could summon wind and thunder, drought and rain. His Dao was divinely manifested and renowned, truly sufficient to adorn the celestial court and bestow blessings upon all beings. Though centuries have passed, people still speak of him with admiration today—how could he be compared to those whose fame flickers briefly before vanishing without a trace?

The *Record of Responses and Transformations* has already documented his meritorious deeds in detail. Yet the Perfected Lord’s teachings for the world, his verses that refine the spirit and awaken the soul, are all capable of rousing the deluded and enlightening the benighted. Had he not wandered in the primordial chaos before the emergence of form, shedding the dust of the world like a cicada molting its shell, utterly free from even the slightest attachment, how could his attainments have reached such heights?

Disciples from all directions recite his words and long to behold them in full, yet regrettably, they have not been preserved in their entirety. Though they were once printed, much has since been lost. Thus, I have gathered them from the famous mountains and re-engraved them upon woodblocks to broaden their transmission. May this enable scholars and seekers to delve beyond the surface of his words, to grasp the secrets of the "fire talisman" and fathom the mysteries of lead and mercury, finding in them an everlasting teacher. Proceeding thus into the realm of the Dao and virtue, one may wander the boundless wilderness, the shores of emptiness, amidst towering peaks and ancient forests on a night when the wind is clear and the moon bright. Chanting his ethereal verses, where the pines echo and the springs respond—who can say that the banners of rainbow clouds and the girdles of rosy mists will not descend? How could such words not be transmitted alongside those of Laozi and Zhuangzi?

I, Yu Chu, unworthy heir to this lineage, am hardly capable of fully extolling his virtues. Yet I fear that some of his teachings may be lost, and so I humbly place this preface at the beginning, awaiting the brush of a master to complete the task.

Written on an auspicious day after the Zhongyuan Festival in the twenty-eighth year of the Hongwu reign (1395), by the Perfected One of Orthodox Unity, Successor to the Dao, Expounder of Non-Action, Inheritor of the Radiant Ancestral Teachings, Leader of the Daoist Religion, and Forty-Third-Generation Celestial Master, Successor to the Han Lineage, Yu Chu, who respectfully bows and offers this preface after fasting and purification.

---

**Recorded Sayings of the Thirtieth-Generation Celestial Master, Perfected Lord of Empty Tranquility, Volume One**
Compiled by Yu Chu, Forty-Third-Generation Celestial Master and Successor

chunks.original_text: 夫心者，万法之宗，九窍之主，生死之本，善恶之源，与天地而并生，为神明之主宰。 或日真君，以其帅长於一体也。 或日真常，以其越古今而不坏也。 或日真如，以其寂然而不动也。 用之则弥满六虚，废之则莫知其所。 〔其〕大无外，则宇宙在其问，而与太虚同体矣。 其小无内，则入秋毫之末，而不可以象求矣。 此所谓我之本心，而空劫以前本来之自己也。 然则果何物哉？ 杳兮冥，恍兮惚，不可以智知，不可以识识，强名日道，强名曰神，强名日心，如此而已。 由是观之，岂不大乎，岂不贵乎。 然而轮迥於三界，出入於生死，而不能自已者，何也？ 盖一念萌动於内，六识流转於外，不超乎善而超乎恶，故有天堂地狱因果之报，六道输回无有出期。 可不痛哉，可不悲哉。 若夫达人则不然也。
chunks.translated_text:
The mind is the root of all dharmas, the master of the nine apertures, the foundation of life and death, and the source of good and evil. It arises together with Heaven and Earth, serving as the sovereign of spirit and luminosity. Some call it the *Perfected Lord*, for it commands the entire body. Some call it *True Constancy*, for it transcends antiquity and modernity without decay. Some call it *True Suchness*, for it abides in stillness, unmoved. When activated, it pervades the six directions; when abandoned, its whereabouts are unknown. Vast beyond measure, the cosmos lies within it, and it shares the same essence as the Great Void. Minute beyond limit, it enters the tip of an autumn hair, yet cannot be sought through form.

This is what we call our fundamental mind, the original self before the empty kalpas. Yet what, truly, is it? Vague and obscure, elusive and indistinct—it cannot be known by intellect, nor grasped by perception. We forcefully name it the *Dao*, forcefully name it *spirit*, forcefully name it *mind*—nothing more. From this, can we not see its greatness? Can we not see its preciousness?

Yet why, though it revolves through the Three Realms, passing in and out of life and death, cannot free itself? For when a single thought stirs within, the six senses flow outward without cease, failing to transcend evil even as it transcends good. Thus arise the retributions of heaven and hell, the karmic consequences, the endless cycles of the Six Paths with no hope of escape. How grievous! How lamentable!

The enlightened, however, are not thus.

chunks.original_text: 故斋戒以神明其德，一真澄湛，万祸消灭。 老子日：致虚极，守静笃，万物并作，吾以观其复。 夫物芸芸，各归其根，归根曰静，静日复命，复命日常，知常日明，不知常妄作，凶。 所谓常者，越古今而不坏者是也。 所谓妄者，一念才起者是也。 庄子日：既以为物矣，欲复归根，不亦难乎。 在易也，其为大人乎。 自兹以往，慎言语，节饮食，除垢止念，静心守一，虚无恬淡，寂寞无为，收视返听，和光同尘。 瞥起是病，不续是药。 不怕念起，惟恐觉迟。 譬如有发，朝朝思理。 有身有心，胡不如是，行住坐外，勿使须臾离也。 无何有之乡，华胥氏之国，吾其游焉。 开坛法兹关 君不见千丈梯，倚於峻岭，蹑之可至颠峰，临於陆地，则数尺墙不可越。 梯非不及，所立者非。 万斛之舟，安於大川，济之可涉江海，委於漱水，则数步溪不可渡。 舟非不能，所安者非。 吾家法录，上可以动天地，下可以撼山川，明可以役龙虎，幽可以摄鬼神，功可以起朽骸，修可以脱生死，大可以镇邦家，小可以却灾祸。 然得之在修，失之在堕。 故匠者与规绳，不能使必巧； 师者与模范，不能使必行。 但人之恩情魔阻，名利障难，罪衅日增，未尝少息。 生形无父母，身外谁亲？ 度日不过衣粮，积之何用？ 荣华富贵，秉烛当风，恩爱妻儿，同枝宿乌。 高车大马，难将长夜之游。 美妾艳妻，宁救九幽之苦。 雕墙峻宇，白玉黄金，偶尔属君，不可长守。 茫茫三界，碌碌四生，一逐逝波，永沉苦海。 莫待邓都使至，黑簿勾名。 到此悔之，何及今日。 汝去父母国，来亲师匠门，蹑踌担双，冲霜冒雨，倾肝涤胆，来瞻太上之真风，责信投名，拜受天师之秘录。 从兹已去，革故日新，名虽奏於高穹，身尚拘於世网。 从前恩爱，割绝渐休，日后冤憎，相逢莫结。 惟是解纷挫锐，济物救人，养性安恬，存神静虑。 攀绿既断，火必息於心猿； 妄想不生，内自停於意马。 知身是患，见命为真，阳不煦生，阴不幽死。 自是大风不动，劫火难烧，念既绝於三尸，性岂着於五欲。 瑶台阅苑，为自己之家乡； 爱海恩山，是他人之活计。 人生何定，白首难期，日月迅速，下手犹迟，若更蹉跎，空成潦倒。 此生幸到宝山，不得回时空手。 伏愿皇基永固，圣寿延长，四夷不战，来王万国。 无私自化，然后十方三界，六道四生，一切有情，俱登道岸。 今则玄坛已就，开度俄临，不敢久立学人。 伏惟珍重。 答池州太守书
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, through fasting and abstinence, one illuminates their virtue with spirit—once the One True [qi] settles into clarity, the ten thousand calamities dissolve. Laozi said: *"Attain utmost emptiness, guard stillness firmly; the ten thousand things arise together, and I observe their return."* All things flourish in abundance, each returning to its root. Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called restoring the mandate; restoring the mandate is called constancy. To know constancy is called clarity; not knowing constancy, one acts recklessly and invites misfortune.

What is called *constancy* is that which transcends past and present without decay. What is called *recklessness* is the moment a single thought arises. Zhuangzi said: *"Once a thing is made, to return again to the root—is this not difficult?"* In the *Yijing*, is this not the way of the *Great Person*?

From this point onward, be cautious in speech, moderate in diet, eliminate defilement and halt thoughts. Still the mind and guard the One; embrace emptiness, tranquility, and non-action. Withdraw the gaze and reverse the hearing; harmonize with radiance and merge with dust. A fleeting thought’s arising is the illness; its non-continuation is the cure. Fear not the arising of thoughts—only the delay in awakening. Like hair that must be combed daily, so too the body and mind—why not tend to them thus? In walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, let not a single moment pass without vigilance.

The land of *Nothing-Whatsoever*, the realm of *Huaxu*—there shall I wander.

**Opening the Altar, Initiating the Rite**

Have you not seen the thousand-foot ladder leaning against the steep ridge? Step upon it, and you may reach the summit; place it upon flat ground, and even a low wall becomes insurmountable. The ladder is not insufficient—it is the ground upon which it stands that is amiss. A ship of ten thousand *hu* rests securely upon the great river; with it, one may cross oceans; cast it upon a shallow stream, and even a few paces become impassable. The ship is not incapable—it is the waters that bear it which are unfit.

The scriptures of my lineage—above, they can move heaven and earth; below, they can shake mountains and rivers. In brightness, they command dragons and tigers; in darkness, they subdue ghosts and spirits. In merit, they can revive the decayed; in cultivation, they can transcend life and death. In greatness, they can stabilize nations; in smallness, they can avert disasters. Yet their attainment lies in practice, and their loss lies in negligence. Thus, the craftsman’s tools and measuring line cannot guarantee skill; the master’s model and standard cannot ensure conduct. Yet man’s karmic obstructions—emotional entanglements, demonic hindrances, the snares of fame and profit—accumulate daily without respite.

Born without parents, who is truly kin beyond the body? Each day requires only clothing and food—what use is hoarding? Glory, wealth, and honor are like a candle in the wind; beloved wives and children are like crows roosting on the same branch. Fine carriages and grand steeds cannot accompany you on the long night’s journey; beautiful concubines and radiant wives cannot rescue you from the ninefold darkness. Carved walls and towering halls, white jade and yellow gold—though they may belong to you for a time, they cannot be kept forever.

Vast are the Three Realms, bustling are the Four Forms of Life—once swept away by the passing current, you sink forever in the sea of suffering. Do not wait until the underworld’s emissary arrives to summon your name from the black ledger. By then, regret will be too late.

You have left your homeland and parents to draw near the gates of masters and teachers, shouldering your burden through frost and rain, baring your liver and cleansing your gall to behold the true wind of the Most High. You have pledged faith and submitted your name to receive the celestial master’s secret scriptures. From this day forward, cast off the old and renew yourself daily. Though your name may be recorded in the highest heavens, your body remains entangled in the world’s net. Sever past attachments gradually; let future grievances pass without entanglement. Only then—dissolving conflicts, blunting sharpness, aiding beings, and saving others—nurture tranquility, preserve spirit, and still the mind.

Once the green vine is cut, the fire of the *monkey-mind* must cease; when deluded thoughts do not arise, the *horse-mind* within naturally halts. Know the body as affliction; see life as the true. The yang does not cherish birth; the yin does not conceal death. Thus, the great wind cannot stir you, and the kalpa’s fire cannot burn you. Thoughts extinguished from the Three Corpses, nature untainted by the Five Desires.

The Jasper Terrace and the Park of Paradise become your homeland; the sea of love and mountain of affection are the livelihoods of others. Human life is uncertain—who can guarantee a full span of years? The days and months pass swiftly; to act is already late. If you delay further, you will only grow feeble and despondent. Having fortunately arrived at this treasure mountain, do not return empty-handed.

I humbly pray that the imperial foundation remain ever firm, the sage’s longevity extend without end, the four barbarians lay down their arms, and the ten thousand kingdoms come to pay homage. Once selfless transformation is achieved, then the ten directions, the Three Realms, the Six Paths, the Four Forms of Life, and all sentient beings shall ascend the shore of the Dao.

Now the altar is prepared, and the rite of initiation is at hand. I dare not linger before the disciple. I implore you—take care.

**Reply to the Prefect of Chizhou**

chunks.original_text: 马休根来，特承附书，复审已移成都，虽跋涉少劳，所履泰定。 法录且埃盟申，谨须躬临盟佩，以全仪式。 因风聊布手诚，休根去别奉状。 六月十三日，某上望之太守。 答真定府太守书 久违冰表，遽损琼缄，喜闻起居，克臻冲适。 欣惟安府侍郎，结发从道，奋身守儒，浩乎学海之巨波，卓尔文林之伟杰。 伫看大用，以副群心，即遂参承，但探欣择。 某上真定府太守。 答汤明权启 某启：久服徽名，阻亲玄论，仰斗每劳於梦寐，披风远隔於姻霞，云会未遑，琼缄首辱，荷至诚之尤甚，顾鄙野以何堪。 共惟明权，玉阙高仙，瑶台上客，弃利名之缰锁，务道德之枢机。 罔象存神，探玄珠於赤水。 恬和养性，合至理於华胥。 更宜拯济难危，提引愚下，全尽真人之德，发挥太上之风。 庶几羽盖龙鳞，共访华阳之境。 蕾买旌霓辈，同游太极之天。 答太守林公书 曩者所授功法，乃得圣师口诀，更在勤行。 虽然不白日轻举，亦得身色无遗，在世延年，长生不死矣。 奉祝，奉祝。 某上林公道友。

**Reply to Magistrate Ma Xiugen**

I have received your letter, and learned with joy that you have been transferred to Chengdu. Though the journey may have wearied you slightly, your path is now secure and your circumstances settled. The ritual register has been prepared, and I must personally attend to the conferral of the sacred pledge to complete the ceremony. I take this opportunity to convey my sincerest regards; Xiugen, you will soon depart, and I shall send a separate reply.

The thirteenth day of the sixth month,
[Your name] respectfully addresses Prefect Wang.

---

**Reply to the Prefect of Zhen Ding Prefecture**

It has been long since we last exchanged words, and now I receive your letter with sorrow. Yet I rejoice to hear of your well-being, which has attained perfect harmony. I am delighted to learn that Minister An of your prefecture, who from youth has followed the Dao and devoted himself to Confucian learning, stands as a towering wave in the vast ocean of scholarship and a peerless luminary in the forest of letters. I await the day his great talents are put to use, fulfilling the hopes of all. Should I have the chance to meet him, I would seek his guidance with eagerness.

[Your name] respectfully addresses the Prefect of Zhen Ding Prefecture.

---

**Reply to Tang Mingquan**

I have long admired your illustrious name, yet our exchange of profound discourse has been hindered. Gazing toward the Dipper in my dreams, I yearn for your presence, but the winds and clouds keep us apart. Though we have not yet met, I am honored to receive your letter, overwhelmed by your sincerity, and unworthy of such kindness.

I trust that Mingquan, a lofty immortal of the Jade Palace and a guest of the Jasper Terrace, has cast aside the shackles of fame and profit to master the pivot of Dao and virtue. You preserve the formless and nurture the spirit, seeking the luminous pearl in the Red Waters. With tranquility, you cultivate your nature, uniting with the supreme principle in the land of Huaxu. You should further aid those in peril, guide the ignorant, fulfill the virtue of the perfected, and manifest the teachings of the Most High. Then, perhaps, we may ride feathered canopies and dragon scales together to visit the realm of Huayang, or join the ranks of cloud banners and rainbow standards in the celestial expanse of the Great Ultimate.

---

**Reply to Prefect Lin**

The methods of practice previously transmitted to you were the oral instructions of a sacred master, and their efficacy depends on diligent cultivation. Though you may not ascend in broad daylight, you will attain an unblemished body, prolong your years in this world, and achieve immortality.

With deepest reverence, I offer my blessings.
[Your name] respectfully addresses Daoist Companion Lin.

chunks.original_text: 答林灵素书 瓢笠无情，云烟奚取。 金门红雾，漫为天上之游。 白石清泉，方保山中之适。 萍梗偶成於会合，云泥各致其逍遥。 一隔江山，屡移寒暑，闲名日起，浪迹时睽。 靖惟道本自然，神非别有，明月周流碧汉，光本无形； 白云来去青山，色非有迹。 蚤入茧而蛾去，雀赴水而蛤生。 变化斯须，循环影响，趋向不干於模拟，浮沉自得於方圆。 万象有杀有生，春花秋落； 一气互消互息，夜露朝晞。 五湖放浪於扁舟，三岛翱翔於玄鹤。 升高须远，就下无难，不昧先机，方为达者。 远承梅驿，径复华笺，幸阀冲和，适符败记。 传天师与弟青词 昔三天之后，父往而子来，今诸录之师，兄辞而弟受。 当小臣之披戴，祈太极以鉴知，将储福於微躬，实难忘於大赐。 臣无任。 谢官职表 时不迨人，恨蒙天眷，恩沾同气，庆洽私门。 自愧宠惊实增，欣扑诚惶诚恐。 伏念臣顷当总角，获奉清光，七换岁华，三颁诏节，构漏弃云眉之宇，以便焚修； 赐宣和御礼之经，俾成功行。 俄下漏泉之泽，及臣同产之兄，遭遇瑜涯，报称何地。 兹盖伏遇特崇，教范无问，颛蒙义重天伦，推及臣子。 虽绿故例，实骇当时。 犬马之心，所当自竭，凤鸾之宇，何极其荣。 中婵香火之诚，上祝冈陵之寿，臣瞻天望圣，激切屏营之至。 谨言。 三十代天师虚靖真君语录卷之一竟 三十代天师虚靖真君语录卷之二 嗣孙四十三代天师宇初编次 五言古诗 同石元规讲鸥鹏偶书
chunks.translated_text:
**Reply to Lin Lingsu**

The gourd and bamboo hat are indifferent things—what use are clouds and mist? The golden gates and crimson haze may seem like celestial wanderings, yet only white stones and limpid springs preserve the mountain’s true tranquility. Our meeting was but a fleeting convergence of duckweed and driftwood, while each of us finds our own path to freedom. Divided by rivers and mountains, seasons have turned again and again; idle fame grows daily, while my wandering traces remain scattered.

I reflect that the Dao is fundamentally natural, and spirit is nothing apart from it. The bright moon courses through the azure sky, yet its light has no form; white clouds drift over green mountains, yet their hue leaves no trace. The silkworm enters its cocoon and the moth departs; the sparrow plunges into water and the clam is born. Transformation occurs in an instant, cycles follow like echoes—no need to imitate, for rise and fall come naturally to the round and square alike. The myriad phenomena know birth and decay, as spring flowers wither in autumn; the single qi waxes and wanes, as night dew vanishes at dawn.

I drift across the five lakes in a small boat, soar over the three isles on a black crane. Ascending high requires distance, descending low presents no difficulty—only by not obscuring the subtle signs does one become a person of true understanding.

Your plum-scented letter, delivered by courier, has just arrived, and I am fortunate that your serene harmony aligns with my fading recollections.

**Memorial from the Celestial Master to the Divine Brother**

In ancient times, after the Three Heavens, fathers departed and sons succeeded; now, among the masters of the registers, elder brothers step aside and younger brothers assume their place. As your humble servant dons the vestments, I pray the Great Ultimate will witness and know: though I seek to store blessings within this unworthy self, I can never forget the great gift bestowed.

I am at a loss for words.

**Memorial of Gratitude for Official Appointment**

The times do not wait for men, and I regret being favored by celestial grace. The kindness extends to my kin, bringing joy to my private household. I am ashamed that such honor truly overwhelms me, and my joy is mingled with awe and trepidation.

I recall that from the time I was but a youth with unbound hair, I was blessed to receive your radiant light. Seven years have passed, and three imperial decrees have been issued—granting me a dwelling with cloud-browed eaves to facilitate my devotions, and bestowing the *Yuli Jing* of the Xuanhe reign to aid my cultivation and practice. Then came the grace of the "Leaking Spring," extending even to my elder brother of the same womb, whose encounter with the boundless was beyond any repayment I could offer.

This is all due to your singular elevation of the teachings, your boundless compassion that knows no distinction, and your profound regard for the bonds of heaven and kin, which you have extended even to me. Though precedent exists, it still astonishes the age. My devotion, like that of a dog or horse, is what I must offer; the splendor of the phoenix and simurgh is beyond all measure.

With the sincerity of incense and flame, I pray for the eternal longevity of the imperial hills. Gazing toward the heavens and longing for the sagely presence, my emotions are as urgent as if I stood at the edge of an abyss.

Respectfully submitted.

*End of the First Scroll of the Recorded Sayings of the Thirty-Sixth Celestial Master, the Vacant Tranquility Perfected Lord*

chunks.original_text: 翱翔数仞问，何异九万里。 大道荡无名，无彼亦无此。 悼哉元规爷，斯言迨尽矣。 一物自太极，志士标高拟。 鹏乎与蜩鸠，涉辩非至理。 有形相变化，不出六合裹。 飞跃涉程途，底用嘲远迩。 乃识逍遥游，泽远发玄旨。 讲罢四窗问，忘言空隐几。 〔内史来访〕 运使徐中奉，寻李隐者于本部，因临访上清，遂得煮茶款话，至夜分乃散。 明自悦耳，信有瑰伟崇高，变通之论，山川之秀亦有增。 明日分袂。 时宣和五年，其略於是篇也。 西风初飘飘，白露仍瓖瓖。 有人浮大川，东巡抵饶阳。 实受九重书，因之访丹房。 山气龙虎明，青林云表长。 与予适相值，议论清冰霜。 已暮更秉烛，坐偶新月冻。 玉蟾翳姻景，金飕扇天香。 影落如乡云，斓然献奇祥。 六合无异色，五峰同秋光。 锦袍谪尘世，骑鲸隔川梁。 君期践玄约，缈缈空中翔。 汤明权挈家入道 佳汝久虚淡，有才弗愿仕。 鸡犬白云间，挈家从游此。 所蕴既超特，玄理可坐致。 悼哉明主命，不以夺我志。 一变江海才，总无尘土气。 闻之旌阳令，拔宅脱凡世。 此事在精修，勉旗汤氏子。 书龙变轩事乃成颂白青城道伯 一室绝尘埃，和风撼瑶竹。 满几惟琴书，潇然异尘俗。 时时操寸毫，节篆数囊录。 或同务玄子，揪枰两三局。 夜对隔林月，膝上奏神曲。 更深兴未阑，徐徐启缄轴。 好来青城君，云开远山绿。 和元规拜违 才到巍峨畔，还登翠碧重。 调青赓白雪，琴静抚黄锺。 履践古人道，追游仙者踪。 自来多福力，相信各疏慵。 何处不为乐，此心知所从。 还如一片月，挂在万年松。 思青城翁 一别青城翁，今经数旬朔。 天炎春气阑，山花旋零落。 时时与攀慕，西眺步瑶阁。 无乃恋人间，笙歌正酣乐。 归来方外俦，践我绿岩约。 回照闪余辉，芙蓉出金削。 和元规见勉 君词语中，具引先贤事。 了然道在兹，不行而善至。 君今真至矣，奏乐求真知。 一言见吾子，固难尽於辞。 知君贯老庄，赛昼蹈大荒。 剧谈玄中玄，豁落无边旁。 有学必有待，不与诸魔对。 涉景若与知，何尝讶谲怪。 疑论涣已释，则信为善士。 主善以为师，天真坐可致。 人间犹论分，仙事宜任运。 有命终出伦，盍死即待尽。 大道非罔象，明明万物上。 使我一闻知，应是快神爽。 休更论浅深，斯言尽诚心。 时哉且落魄，此语吾所钦。 傍听亦吃嗤，不责於仁慈。 所幸异流俗，事物中思惟。 和张知县省食费韵 食撰不须丰，古人贵量腹。 一饱尚何求，八珍非所欲。 犀筋驮未下，但折平生禄。 造物赋人料，多少有数目。 更思途中俘，皆缘食不足。 庄叟重鹁食，此篇时一读。 又省衣 衣服贵适宜，冬裘与夏葛。 睠兹修行人，初不事精洁。 轻纱并丽帛，样新价亦别。 每缣数千钱，拙工乱裁截。 些小未称身，中心已不悦。 曾知有贫者，冬夏皆皮裂。 三十代天师虚靖真君语录卷之二竟 三十代天师虚靖真君语录卷之三

**Five-Character Ancient Verse**

*Written in Response to Shi Yuangui’s Discourse on the Gull and Roc*

Soaring but a few *ren* in flight—
how differs it from ninety thousand *li*?
The Great Dao drifts, nameless,
without "that" or "this."

Alas, Master Yuangui,
such words near their end.
All things arise from the Supreme Ultimate;
the steadfast set their lofty aims.
Yet gull and roc,
in debate, miss the highest truth.
Forms shift and change,
but never leave the Six Directions’ bounds.
Leaping or soaring, traversing paths—
why mock near or far?
Only then is known the *xiaoyaoyou*,
its distant gleam revealing the profound intent.

The discourse done, the four windows stilled,
words forgotten, the desk left empty.

---

**[The Prefect’s Visit]**
Commissioner Xu of the Bureau of Operations sought the Recluse Li in his district, then came to visit Shangqing. There, we boiled tea and spoke at length, parting only at midnight. His words were a delight to the ear—truly grand, lofty, and transformative. Even the mountains and rivers seemed more radiant. The next day, we bade farewell.

At the time, it was the fifth year of Xuanhe. Here follows a brief account:

The west wind first stirs, light,
white dew still glistening.
A man floats down the great river,
eastward to Raoyang.
He bears a decree from the Ninefold Throne,
and so seeks the cinnabar chambers.
Mountain *qi* gleams with dragon and tiger,
green forests stretch beyond the clouds.
By chance, he meets me—
our discourse sharp as frost.
Dusk falls, and we take up candles;
seated beneath the new moon’s chill.
The jade toad veils the misty scene,
golden breezes waft celestial fragrance.
Shadows fall like hometown clouds,
brilliant, offering wondrous omens.
The Six Directions share no other hue,
the Five Peaks bathe in autumn’s light.
A brocade-robed exile in the dusty world,
riding a whale, he parts the river’s beams.
You await the fulfillment of our mystic pact,
soaring ethereal in the empty sky.

---

**Tang Mingquan Takes His Family into the Dao**
How fine, your long-held detachment,
your talent unused for office!
Amid white clouds, chickens and dogs,
you lead your family to wander here.
Your hidden depths are extraordinary—
profound principles may be attained in stillness.
Alas, the enlightened lord’s decree
could not sway your resolve.
Transformed into a river-and-sea talent,
utterly free of worldly dust.
I hear of Magistrate Jingyang,
who raised his household beyond the mortal realm.
Such matters lie in earnest cultivation—
strive on, scion of the Tang!

---

**A Eulogy on the Dragon-Transforming Pavilion, Presented to the Daoist Master of Qingcheng**
A chamber free of dust,
harmonious winds sway jade bamboo.
The desk holds only zither and books,
untrammeled, apart from the vulgar world.
Now and then, he wields his brush,
transcribing talismans and tallying records.
Or he joins Master Wu Xuan,
playing two or three games of *liubo*.
At night, beneath the moon beyond the woods,
he plays divine melodies upon his knee.
Deep into the night, his interest unspent,
he slowly unfurls the scrolls.
Come, Master of Qingcheng,
as clouds part, distant mountains turn green.

---

**In Response to Yuan Gui’s Farewell**
Just arrived at the towering peaks,
I ascend again the verdant heights.
Tuning the zither’s green strings to "White Snow,"
in stillness, I pluck "Yellow Bell."
Treading the path of the ancients,
pursuing the traces of immortals.
Since coming here, I’ve known abundant fortune—
yet I trust in each other’s carefree ease.
Where is there no joy?
This heart knows its course.
Like a single slice of moon
hanging on the ten-thousand-year pine.

---

**Thinking of the Elder of Qingcheng**
Since parting from the Elder of Qingcheng,
now several months have passed.
The scorching sky, spring’s breath waning,
mountain blossoms swiftly scatter.
Time and again, I yearn and gaze,
westward, pacing the jade pavilion.
Surely he lingers among men,
where pipes and songs still revel in delight.
Return, companion of the world beyond—
fulfill our pact at Green Cliff.
The setting sun flashes its lingering glow,
lotus rising from golden carving.

---

**In Response to Yuan Gui’s Encouragement**
Your words, sir, cite the ancients,
making clear the Dao resides here—
without action, yet goodness arrives.
Now you have truly attained it,
offering music to seek true knowledge.
A single phrase reveals your nature,
though words can scarcely contain it.
I know you have mastered Lao and Zhuang,
striding through the vast wilds by day.
In spirited discourse on the mystery within mystery,
you stand unbounded, without limit.
To learn, one must have something to await—
not contending with the myriad demons.
Gazing at the scene, as if knowing,
why marvel at the strange or uncanny?
Doubts dispelled, trust is born—
then you are truly a good man.
Take goodness as your teacher,
and the celestial truth may be attained in stillness.
Men still debate rank and station,
but the affairs of immortals should follow spontaneity.
If fate decrees one surpasses the common,
why wait for death to end all?
The Great Dao is no empty illusion—
luminous, it stands above the ten thousand things.
Hearing this once, I feel
my spirit refreshed, my soul invigorated.
Cease debating depth or shallowness—
these words express a heart sincere.
The times are such that I am fallen,
yet I cherish this saying.
Though others may scoff in passing,
they cannot fault its kindness.
Fortunate to differ from the vulgar,
I ponder these matters deeply.

---

**Matching Rhymes with Magistrate Zhang on Reducing Food Expenses**
No need for lavish fare—
the ancients prized moderation.
One meal’s sufficiency, what more to seek?
The Eight Delicacies are not my desire.
Before the rhinoceros chopsticks are laid,
I have already forfeited my life’s allotment.
The Creator apportions to each their measure,
how much or little, fixed in number.
Think further of those starving on the road—
all from lack of food.
Master Zhuang valued the pigeon’s meal—
this passage should be read again and again.

---

**Also on Reducing Clothing**
Clothing should suit the season—
winter furs and summer linen.
Consider the diligent practitioner,
who at first cares not for finery.
Light silks and fine brocades,
new styles, their prices varied.
A few thousand coins for each bolt,
clumsy tailors hacking at random.
A trifling misfit, yet the heart is displeased.
Have you known the poor,
whose skin cracks in winter and summer alike?

*End of the Second Scroll of the Recorded Sayings of the Thirty-Sixth Celestial Master, the Vacant Tranquility Perfected Lord*

chunks.original_text: 嗣孙四十三代天师宇初编次 歌行 大道歌 道不远，在身中，物则皆空性不空。 性若不空和气住，气归元海寿无穷。 欲得身中神不出，莫向灵台留一物。 物在身中神不清，耗散精神损筋骨。 神驭气，气留形，不须杂术自长生。 术则易知道难悟，既然悟得不专行。 所以千人万人学，毕竟终无一二成。 神若出，便收来，神返身中气自回。 如此朝朝还暮暮，自然赤子产真胎。 虚空歌 虚空荡荡无边岸，日月东西互宾饯。 东宾西饯几时休，生死场中如掣电。 本来真性同虚空，光明朗耀无昏蒙。 偶因一念落形体，为他生死迷西东。 堪叹世人全不觉，死即哀兮生即乐。 不知生是死根由，只喜东升怕西落。 东升西落理当然，休将情识相牵缠。 不信但看日与月，朝昏上下常周天。 生非来兮死非去，无有相因随所寓。 六道轮回浪着忙，真人止在虚空住。 真人住处无室庐，邻风伴月同清虚。 莫谓灵光只些子，包罗法界无遗余。 法界包罗大无外，密入纤尘小无内。 饥寒灾祸不能加，物物头头归主宰。 一堆尘土百年形，如舟泛水凭人行。 忽朝舟坏人登岸，枯木无主从沉倾。 莫腐莫回顾万水，千江几番渡这回。 到岸好焚舟不须，更说波涛苦有绿。 舟居不居终不虞，昨夜风雷撼山岳。 虚空不动常如如，识得真空方不昧。 古往今来镇长在，掀翻世界露全身。 尽度众生超苦海，真空消息非顽空。 纵横变化无终穷，听我一歌空裹曲，铁蛇飞上昆仑峰。 休歇歌 休休休，歇歇歇，休休歇歇无分别。 千般要妙万般玄，只是教人各休歇。 既能休，复能歇，一切情绿皆断绝。 饥愤渴饮困时眠，万死千生没交涉。 古圣贤，及明哲，一性绵绵周浩劫。 光明相照合真空，休歇之余更无别。 地狱种，作冤业，六识炽然如火热。 立我争人昧休歇，甘受碎身并拔舌。 休与歇，真口诀，无愚无智无工拙。 从上师真只怨修，不遇知心谁肯泄。 休非休，歇非歇，大用现前无扭捏。 主张元化绝形踪，囊括虚空超起灭。 亦无休，亦无歇，歇歇休休皆强说。 欲知真歇与真休，一输皎洁中秋月。 钱塘有作 红霞映朱栏，白云隐青山。 尘中人不到，双鹤舞柴关。 瑶琴一曲诗数篇，山童煮茗炉无姻。 为思尘世去游乐，一别洞天今几年。 湘江江上月初白，湘浦浦边风色清。 断肠声咽玉笛碎，愁杀霜堤多少情。 人生总浮云。 仙家依旧春，归去来兮乐吾真。 和元规任从他歌 任从他，尽教他，莫管他，他是他非奈我何。 尽日闲同方外友，高吟落笔如悬河。 世上无心结凡累，匣中有剑降阴魔。 长生已悟玄关旨，从教乌兔走如梭。 尘劳汨没诚堪恶，孰肯飘荡随蹉跎。 静处每思喧处事，到头空自竞嘘呵。 任从他，尽教他，莫管他，但从元气养冲和。 有时恣把丹书读，无事闲寻玉轸歌。 我心非石不可动，任从俗论生乖讹。 松簪布褐且自乐，岂恋俘华张锜罗。 神炉交媾炼金液，混乎湛湛而日多。 功行圆成共归去，飘飘飞盖拂霄河。 任从他，尽教他，莫管他。 橐钥歌 休言大道无为作，须向房中明橐钥。 过时不动片时间，紫雾红光乱灼灼。 青龙喜，白虎恶，赤蛇缠定乌龟壳。 纵然过得尾闾关，又被曹溪路隔着。 两条直上絮丹田，决言上有三清阁。 阁下分明有玉池，内有长生不死药。 依时下手采将来，服了蓬莱受快乐。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Song of the Great Dao**

The Dao is not far—it dwells within the body.
All things are empty, yet nature is not void.
If nature remains unvoid, harmonious qi abides;
qi returns to the primal sea, and life knows no end.

To keep the spirit within the body,
let not a single thing linger in the numinous terrace.
If things remain, the spirit grows unclear,
draining vitality and wasting sinew and bone.

The spirit guides qi, qi sustains form—
no need for miscellaneous arts to attain long life.
Arts are easy to know, but the Dao is hard to fathom;
even when fathomed, one fails to practice it single-mindedly.
Thus, though thousands and tens of thousands study,
in the end, scarcely one or two succeed.

If the spirit strays, bring it back;
when the spirit returns, qi naturally follows.
Morning and evening, thus renewed,
the true embryo of the unblemished child is born.

---

**The Song of Emptiness**

Emptiness stretches boundless, without shore or edge,
sun and moon traverse east and west in mutual farewell.
How long will their eastbound farewells and westbound welcomes last?
In the realm of birth and death, they flash like lightning.

The true nature, originally one with emptiness,
shines bright and clear, free from dimness.
Yet by a single thought, it falls into form,
lost in the cycle of birth and death, wandering east and west.

Alas, how few in the world awaken!
Death brings sorrow, birth brings joy—
unaware that birth is the root of death,
rejoicing in the sun’s rise, dreading its fall.

Eastward rise and westward fall are the natural way;
do not let the heart’s attachments entangle you.
If you doubt, observe the sun and moon—
dawn and dusk, they ceaselessly circle the heavens.

Birth is not arrival, death is not departure;
nothing arises from dependence, all abides where it dwells.
The six paths of rebirth rush in vain—
the true person dwells only in emptiness.

Where the true person dwells, no house stands,
neighboring wind and moon in pure void.
Do not say the numinous light is but a speck—
it encompasses the Dharma realm without omission.

The Dharma realm, vast beyond bounds,
pervades the tiniest dust, yet holds nothing within.
Hunger, cold, and calamity cannot touch it;
every thing, every head, returns to the sovereign.

A heap of dust, a body of a hundred years—
like a boat adrift on water, steered by another’s hand.
Suddenly the boat breaks, the passenger steps ashore;
the withered wood, masterless, sinks and drifts.

Do not rot, do not look back—how many rivers have you crossed?
Countless streams, how many times have you passed this way?
Once ashore, burn the boat—no need for it;
why speak of waves as bitter, their green as sorrow?

Whether dwelling in the boat or not, fear not—
last night’s wind and thunder shook the mountains.
Emptiness remains unmoved, ever thus;
only when you grasp true emptiness will you not be deluded.

From ancient times to now, it stands eternal;
upending the world, it reveals its full body.
Having delivered all beings from the sea of suffering,
the message of true emptiness is no inert void.

Transformations unfold without end—
hear my song within the void,
an iron serpent soaring to Kunlun’s peak.

---

**The Song of Rest**

Rest, rest, rest—cease, cease, cease.
Rest and cease without distinction.
A thousand subtleties, ten thousand mysteries—
all teach but one thing: rest and cease.

If you can rest, if you can cease,
all entanglements of emotion are severed.
Hunger eats, thirst drinks, weariness sleeps—
through ten thousand deaths and a thousand births, no concern remains.

The sages of old, the wise and enlightened,
their single nature endures through eons.
Radiant light illumines, merging with true emptiness—
beyond rest and cessation, nothing else remains.

Those who plant seeds in hell,
who weave karmic debts,
their six senses burn like raging fire.
Clinging to self, contending with others, blind to rest and cessation,
they willingly endure dismemberment and tongue extraction.

Rest and cease—this is the true oral formula,
beyond foolishness, wisdom, skill, or clumsiness.
From ancient teachers, the truth is this:
they lamented those who cultivated without meeting a kindred heart—who would reveal it?

Rest is not rest, cease is not cease—
the great function manifests without pretense.
It governs the primal transformation, leaving no trace,
encompassing emptiness, transcending arising and ceasing.

Neither rest nor cease—
rest and cease are but forced words.
To know true rest and true cessation,
look to the flawless moon of mid-autumn.

---

**Composed at Qiantang**

Crimson clouds reflect the vermilion balustrade,
white clouds veil the green mountains.
Worldly folk never come here—
a pair of cranes dance at the brushwood gate.

A jade zither plays one tune, poems flow in numbers;
the mountain boy boils tea, the stove emits no smoke.
Longing for the world’s pleasures, I wandered away—
how many years have passed since I left this grotto heaven?

On the Xiang River, the moon begins to pale;
by the Xiang’s banks, the wind’s touch is clear.
The jade flute’s broken notes choke with sorrow—
how much grief does the frosty embankment hold?

Human life is but floating clouds.
The immortals’ spring remains—
return, return! Rejoice in my true self.

---

**Matching Yuan Gui’s "Let Them Sing as They Will"**

Let them sing as they will, let them do as they please—
pay them no mind.
Right or wrong, what can they do to me?

All day, I idle with friends beyond the world,
chanting verses, my brush flowing like a torrent.
Unburdened by worldly ties,
my sword in its scabbard subdues yin demons.

I have grasped the mystery of the immortal’s gate—
let the sun and moon shuttle like a loom.
The toil of the dust is truly vile—
who would drift and idle, following the years?

In quietude, I ponder the affairs of the bustling world—
in the end, all is but empty striving.
Let them sing as they will, let them do as they please—
pay them no mind.

Just nurture the primal qi to harmony.
Sometimes, I freely read alchemical texts;
at leisure, I seek songs on the jade zither.
My heart is no stone—it cannot be moved.
Let worldly opinions breed discord—
I wear a pine-wood hairpin and hempen robe, content,
how could I crave the trappings of luxury?

In the divine furnace, the golden elixir is refined,
ever more serene and abundant.
When merit and practice are complete, we shall depart together,
soaring on feathered canopies to brush the River of Stars.

Let them sing as they will, let them do as they please—
pay them no mind.

---

**The Song of the Bellows**

Do not say the Great Dao is effortless action—
you must clarify the bellows within the chamber.
Miss the moment, and not a breath passes;
purple mists and crimson light swirl in brilliance.

The Azure Dragon rejoices, the White Tiger balks,
the Scarlet Serpent coils around the Black Tortoise’s shell.
Even if you pass the Tail Gate,
you are still barred by the path of Cao Creek.

Two paths ascend straight to the cinnabar field—
it is said that above lies the Pavilion of the Three Pure Ones.
Beneath the pavilion, a jade pool is clearly seen,
within it, the elixir of immortality.

Seize the moment, gather it—
having ingested it, enjoy the bliss of Penglai.

Have you known the poor,
whose skin cracks in winter and summer alike?

*End of the Second Scroll of the Recorded Sayings of the Thirty-Sixth Celestial Master, the Vacant Tranquility Perfected Lord*
